texts.definition: Areas in game worlds which can be used to block access to other areas.
markups: <style="Definition">Areas in game worlds which can be used to block access to other areas.</style>

Parts of game worlds can be narrow or otherwise quite difficult to move through. When this funnels movement between different parts of game worlds into small areas, these areas become <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> which can easily be used to hinder access to other parts of the game worlds.

<style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> are used in maps for many multiplayer <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">First-Person Shooters</link></style> as they concentrate gameplay activity. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike">Counter-Strike</link></style> has <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> a numerous <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style>, for example the double doors in the ''Dust2'' map and the stairs to the second floor of the safe-house in the ''Italy'' map. For <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%202">Team Fortress 2</link></style>, examples include the tunnel in the ''Gold Rush'' map and the blue team's initial exit points in the ''Dustbowl'' map. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Battlefield%202">Battlefield 2</link></style>, some areas such as the road across the dam in the ''Kubra Dam'' map may be <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> more for vehicles than pedestrians since those on foot have several alternative routes.

<style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> are also common in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Real-Time%20Strategy%20Games">Real-Time Strategy Games</link></style> such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Starcraft%20series">Starcraft</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Warcraft%20series">Warcraft series</link></style>. For <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Starcraft%20II">Starcraft II</link></style>, the maps ''Incineration Zone'' and ''Kulas Ravine'' especially make heavy use of <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style>. In contrast, tactics exist in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Defense%20of%20the%20Ancients%20series">Defense of the Ancients series</link></style> to exploit <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> near "creep" camps to harvest them more efficiently.

<style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> can be create through designing narrow sections in <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> that solely or together with just a few other <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> provide access between other parts of the <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>. The easiest way to achieve this is through using <style="Link"><link="laning">Laning</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="transport-routes">Transport Routes</link></style>. Alternatively, <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> can be used and <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style> can make the use of <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> a <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Off</link></style> rather than a requirement. Of course, if several <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> exist between the same areas - which makes them into <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style> - then players also have a choice whether to use a particular <style="CurrentLink">Choke Point</style> or not. The existence of <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style> may however make locations stop functioning as <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> if they always offer easier access to other parts of the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. These <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style> can of course contain their own <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style>, complicating the relation between the two patterns. In games with <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> (and <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style>) can be designed so they only apply to vehicular or pedestrian movement. If available, <style="Link"><link="bases">Bases</link></style> are likely to be placed in <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> to control access through them.

<style="Link"><link="galleries">Galleries</link></style> can specifically create <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> through the narrow passages they contain. <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style> can also create <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style>, and this is one way of letting players create them during gameplay if they can create the <style="Link"><link="installations">Installations</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style> can offer the same possibility if they create <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style> when they are destroyed. The efficiency of <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> to block access can be greatly increased if <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> have <style="Link"><link="zone-control">Zone of Control</link></style> abilities.

<style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> can be used to define the limits of <style="Link"><link="arenas">Arenas</link></style>, and can heighten the difference between the open area in <style="Link"><link="arenas">Arenas</link></style> compared to other parts of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. The same applies to <style="Link"><link="vehicle-sections">Vehicle Sections</link></style>, and especially so when the <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> are impassible when using <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> are <style="Link"><link="strategic-locations">Strategic Locations</link></style> that affect how <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> can be done in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, primarily by making <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goals more difficult or by creating <style="Link"><link="conditional-passageways">Conditional Passageways</link></style> when <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> are controlling them or they are blocked by <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style>. By doing so they are often the targets of <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style> goals and this quite naturally leads to <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals also. The resulting <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> against <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> is typically easier or harder than "normal" <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> depending on who controls the <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style>. This can lead to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Repeated%20Domination">Repeated Domination</link></style> but can also likely shift the balance of which weapons are most efficient (powerful but short ranged weapons, such as the flamethrower of the ''Pyro'' in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Team%20Fortress%202">Team Fortress 2</link></style>, is most efficient in <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style>).

Besides creating <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> goals, <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> can create <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> goals and make <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style> goals more difficult. This is even more the case when <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Strongholds">Strongholds</link></style> by being the only ways of getting to gameplay areas. In contrast, <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> can make <style="Link"><link="herd">Herd</link></style> goals easier since they are fewer ways for the herded elements to escape. Providing several <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> for players to try to get access to is an explicit way of creating a <style="Link"><link="selectable-set-goals">Selectable Set of Goals</link></style> (even if games with <style="Link"><link="teams">Teams</link></style> can try several at once).

<style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> in <style="Link"><link="vehicle-sections">Vehicle Sections</link></style> more radically affect gameplay that in other sections since the difference between top speeds and being bogged down is greater; they may also make it preferable to temporary abandon <style="Link"><link="vehicles">Vehicles</link></style> to try an circumvent the <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style>.

An extra effect of <style="CurrentLink">Choke Points</style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> is that they increase the likelihood of players meeting each other.
